Valorization of biomass and plastics is an urgent assignment to achieve the goal of carbon neutrality. Hydrodeoxygenation using bimetallic catalysts with distinct active sites is one of the most effective approaches to producing fuels and chemicals via C–O/C–C bonds hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation. Rational design of bimetallic catalysts has been progressed in recent studies owing to the understanding of synergy and strong mutual interaction between metal nanoparticles and metal oxide species. Thus, activity of bimetallic catalysts has been further improved, and the chemoselectivity for suppression of C–C bond dissociation and the regioselectivity among different C–O bonds, which have less been achieved before, are realized in the hydrodeoxygenation reactions. The catalytic performances, catalyst structures, and reaction mechanisms are directly compared and discussed in details based on the C–O bond cleavage using glycerol and 1,2-propanediol hydrogenolysis as model reactions over Ir-, Pt-, and Ru-based bimetallic catalysts. Finally, application of these bimetallic catalysts to conversion of lignocellulose-derived feedstocks, carbonyl compounds, and typical plastic of polycarbonates is introduced. Graphical Abstract This review discusses bimetallic catalysts, especially those composed of noble metal, early transition metal and support, for hydrodeoxygenation reactions without C-C dissociations. Rational design of this class of catalysts much improves the performance in recent days. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Hydrogenolysis Bimetallic catalyst Biomass derivative Plastic waste 1 Introduction Emission of greenhouse gases, mainly in the form of CO2, causes ever-increasing global warming, which requires urgent suppression of CO2 emission [ 1–3 ]. Transportation produces huge amounts of CO2 by burning fossil fuels such as gasoline and diesel. In this regard, carbon recycling is of great significance to decrease carbon emissions, achieving the goal of carbon neutrality. Direct reduction of CO2 with renewable hydrogen could produce useful hydrocarbons and oxygenates in a sustainable manner. However, synthesis of such oxygenates from CO2 reduction is not compelling relative to petroleum refining industry in terms of energy consumption [ 4 ]. An alternative route is the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass-derived platform chemicals such as sugar alcohols and furan derivatives to valuable oxygenates by selective hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds considering the small difference of oxygen content between the platform chemicals and target oxygenates. Plastic polymers are widely used in everyday life, and monomers for a variety of oxygen-containing plastic products can be obtained by selective HDO of biomass-derived platform chemicals [ 5 ]. For example, HDO of glycerol and succinic acid offers 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PrD) and 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BuD), which are the monomers for manufacturing polytrimethylene terephthalate and polybutylene terephthalate, respectively [ 6,7 ]. Biomass route by HDO technique provides an alternative for production of plastics using traditional petrochemicals. Furthermore, upcycling these oxygen-containing plastic wastes via HDO process would provide useful hydrocarbons for the urgent task of recycling plastic wastes [ 8–11 ]. Regioselective cleavage of C–O/C–N bonds (hydrodeoxygenation with suppression of C–C bond dissociation) in polycarbonate, polyesters, and polyamides is necessary to produce high value-added chemicals instead of light alkanes with low value. These hydrocarbons as well as the biomass-derived ones and bioethanol can be directly used as fuels. In addition, HDO of oxygen-containing aromatic plastics provides hydrocarbons (liquid organic hydrogen carriers) with promising applications in efficient and stable hydrogen storage and transportation [ 12–14 ]. The aforementioned catalytic HDO process mainly includes hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds and/or hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds (Fig. 1 ), and the hydrogenolysis of C–C bonds is generally a side reaction that should be avoided. Unlike simple hydrogenation reactions, catalysts with bifunctional character for activation of both hydrogen and substrate are generally required to realize chemoselective HDO for the production of fuels and chemicals. In particular, when the target product is an oxygenate, regio-selectivity is necessary for the catalysts to activate the substrate at a specific site among multiple oxygen-containing functional groups in the substrate molecule. Combination of two metals on a support for rational design of bimetallic catalysts has been widely investigated for HDO of biomass and their derivatives for more than two decades, whereas application of such catalysts to upcycling oxygen-containing plastic wastes and polymers has received great attention recently [ 15,16 ]. Two metals on a support could be alloyed, individually dispersed, or interacted. Some excellent review articles have well summarized the progress in HDO utilization over bimetallic nanoalloys [ 17 ] as well as noble metals (Pd, Rh, etc.) modified by metal oxide (ReO x , MoO x , WO x , etc.) [ 4,18 ]. In this review, we focus on the recent development of metal oxide-modified noble metal catalysts, especially Ir-, Pt-, and Ru-based ones for HDO reactions, because the structure and performance of this type of catalysts can be precisely controlled, and each catalyst with unique selectivity can be applied to HDO of a wide scope of biomass derivatives [ 4,18,19 ] and plastic wastes [ 10,16,20 ]. Accordingly, the structures of bimetallic catalysts, HDO reaction mechanism, relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic performance, and application of these catalysts for production of valuable chemicals are reviewed. 2 Recent development of bimetallic catalysts for HDO: glycerol or 1,2-propanediol conversion to propanediols or propanols as model reactions Glycerol is widely accessible as a by-product in manufacturing biodiesel fuel by transesterification of triglycerides to fatty acid esters [ 6,21,22 ]. Glycerol has been regarded as one of the most important biomass-derived platform chemicals [ 6 ], and its conversion to useful chemicals including HDO has been intensively investigated. In addition, glycerol is the simplest sugar alcohol with both primary and secondary OH groups, and glycerol hydrogenolysis can be regarded as a model reaction for hydrogenolysis of complex molecules with various types of C–O bonds. The first journal paper on the glycerol hydrogenolysis traces back to 1991 using a Ru-based bimetallic catalyst [ 23 ]. The hydrogenolysis of C–O bond in glycerol with preservation of C–C bond gives propanediols (PrDs) of 1,2-PrD and 1,3-PrD, propanols (PrOHs) of 1-PrOH and 2-PrOH, and overhydrogenolysis product of propane (Fig. 2 ). 1,3-PrD is the most valuable product in the reductive glycerol transformation; however, only a few studies give high selectivity to 1,3-PrD in the glycerol hydrogenolysis (glycerol HDO) due to the difficulties in regioselectivity control and suppression of overhydrogenolysis. On the other hand, synthesis of 1,3-PrD by ethylene oxide hydroformylation and hydrogenation or acrolein hydration-hydrogenation has been gradually abandoned due to the high cost and environmental issues [ 24 ]. The biological production of 1,3-PDO from renewable resources (glycerol, glucose or starch) by fermentation has been commercialized [ 25 ], but it suffers from high separation cost and low productivity [ 26 ]. Hydrogenolysis for production of 1,3-PrD from glycerol has not yet been industrialized, but the high productivity is promising for good scalability with the development of highly active and selective catalysts [ 27 ]. Heterogeneous catalyst development pursuing higher performance, especially higher selectivity to 1,3-PrD, has been very intensively carried out [ 21,27–30 ]. The state-of-the-art systems for the 1,3-PrD production will be explained in this section. 1,2-PrD is another C3 diol from C–O hydrogenolysis of primary OH group in glycerol, which has been achieved with a high yield over Cu-based catalysts [ 31 ], and is now commercially produced from glycerol, though it is less valuable than 1,3-PrD. 1,2-PrD is the simplest molecule with both primary and secondary OH groups, and 1,2-PrD hydrogenolysis can be also regard as a model reaction. The catalysts with good selectivity to 1,3-PrD in the glycerol hydrogenolysis generally show good selectivity to 1-PrOH in the 1,2-PrD hydrogenolysis with the same reaction mechanism [ 32,33 ]. However, the inverse conclusion is not always true: some catalysts with good selectivity to 1-PrOH give rather 1,2-PrD as the major product in the glycerol hydrogenolysis [ 34,35 ]. On the other hand, the hydrogenolysis of 1,2-PrD at the primary C–O bond to 2-PrOH is very difficult, in contrast to the easy hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PrD (hydrogenolysis of one primary C–O bond). Several catalyst candidates, namely Ir-FeO x catalysts, have been discovered only recently for the 1,2-PrD hydrogenolysis to 2-PrOH [ 36,37 ], which will be discussed later in this section. We summarize the performances of typical noble-metal-based catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol with comment(s) in Table 1 . All systems in Table 1 use a water solvent, which is also the best solvent for HDO of other biomass-derived compounds. Older reports (not shown in Table 1) sometimes used polar organic solvents such as 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (DMI) [ 38,39 ], but the use of this kind of solvent is not preferred in view of green chemistry. Ir-based bimetallic catalysts (entries 1–6) have controllable unique selectivity. The combination with Re species (Ir-ReO x /support catalysts) is especially important since they produce 1,3-PrD with good activity at relatively low temperature. While most reports for Ir-M'O x catalysts used water solvent including those for other substrates, alkane solvents can be also used for less polar substrates [ 40,41 ]. Pt-based catalysts are usually combined with W species and used for the 1,3-PrD production (entries 7–15). The activity of Pt-based catalysts for the 1,3-PrD production is generally lower than those of Ir-based ones (lower rate per noble metal amount and higher reaction temperature); however, recent catalyst development much improved the activity. Ru is an active component for hydrogenolysis reaction even when used as a monometallic catalyst, especially when combined with an acid (entry 16). In addition to the difficulty in the regioselectivity of C–O hydrogenolysis, C–C hydrogenolysis also occurs over monometallic Ru catalysts. However, appropriately designed bimetallic Ru-MO x catalysts can suppress the C–C hydrogenolysis (entries 17–19). Rh catalysts such as Rh-ReO x /SiO2 are also very active in the C–O hydrogenolysis of glycerol at similar low temperature (~393 K) to Ir-ReO x catalysts (entry 20). However, it shows low regioselectivity in the formation of diols, and the main product is 1-PrOH [ 42 ]. Considering the high cost of Rh and lower controllability than Ir-based bimetallic catalysts, Rh-based catalysts were investigated in earlier studies [ 43–47 ], and such catalysts were less developed for the glycerol hydrogenolysis in the past 10 years. The details of the recent development and each system of Ir-, Pt-, and Ru-based bimetallic catalysts will be explained in the following sections. Most catalysts in Table 1 are composed of noble metal (M), group 6 or 7 metal oxide (M'O x ) and support, and SiO2 is the most frequently used support. The effectiveness of SiO2 support can be explained by the weak interaction between the support and M'O x , which leads to the formation of M-M'O x interface sites. If the M'O x species are bonded more strongly with M than with a support, the M'O x species tend to exist on the surface of M particles (type A in Fig. 3 ), and the M-M'O x interface sites are rich in this type of catalyst. On the other hand, if the interaction between M and M'O x is weaker than that between a support and M'O x , the M and M'O x species tend to be separately located on the support, especially when it is also weaker than that between M and support (type B in Fig. 3). The combination of Pt and WO x is the typical case for type B, and there are several approaches to overcome the difficulty to build the interaction between Pt and WO x . Adjusting the interaction between M (Pt) and M'O x (WO x ) stronger than that between M (Pt) and support is one possible approach (type C), which is actually realized in Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst with low W amount. The Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst will be explained in detail in a later section. It should be noted that the structure of each type of bimetallic catalysts is stable under their optimized reaction conditions. 2.1 Ir-based bimetallic catalysts 2.1.1 Recent improvement of Ir-ReOx catalysts: Strengthening mutual interaction of Ir-ReOx pairs Ir-based catalysts are important class of HDO catalysts with unique selectivity. As the first Ir-based C–O hydrogenolysis catalyst, Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (4 wt% Ir, Re/Ir = 1) was reported by our group in the study of glycerol hydrogenolysis in 2010 [ 48 ]. In fact, it is difficult to find such combination since both metals are almost inactive when employed individually [ 18 ]. The strong affinity between the two elements unexpectedly enables glycerol to be selectively converted into 1,3-PrD with high activity. The selectivity to 1,3-PrD in the initial stage of the reaction (ca. 70%) is still the highest level among all the catalysts developed for glycerol hydrogenolysis so far, although the overhydrogenolysis of 1,3-PrD to 1-PrOH is significant over this Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst. Characterization results suggest a nanostructure of Ir nanoparticles (~2 nm) covered with three-dimensional ReO x clusters [ 66 ]. However, the addition of H2SO4 as a promoter was necessary to maximize the activity of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 at that time [ 32,48 ]. Later, a solid acid zeolite, namely HZSM-5 [ 49,67 ], was used as an alternative promoter to H2SO4 (major product of 1,3-PrD or propane dependent on the reaction conditions) due to the potential reactor corrosion. The Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst is simple and easy to be prepared. The catalyst has been sometimes used in other reactions, and some reports will be explained in the later section. The improvement of the catalyst had been unsuccessful until recently. In 2019, we reported Ir-ReO x /SiO2 with improved activity and good selectivity by increasing the Ir loading amount up to 20 wt% (Re/Ir = 0.34, actual) under acid-free conditions (Fig. 4 ) [ 33 ]. The Ir nanoparticles were not obviously aggregated at 20 wt% due to the high BET specific surface area of SiO2 (S BET > 450 m2 g–1). In the same year, another highly active catalyst of Ir-ReO x /TiO2 (4 wt% Ir, Re/Ir = 0.24) was found by screening effective support to disperse Ir-ReO x particles (Fig. 5(A) ). It is very interesting that Ir-ReO x /TiO2 with the small surface area (S BET of 6 m2 g–1, rutile TiO2) could significantly improve the catalytic performance [ 50 ]. In contrast, anatase or P25 (mixture of rutile and anatase) gave much lower conversions. The loading content of Ir was also optimized (Fig. 5(B)); the optimum amount was about 4 wt%–6 wt%, which is smaller than that on the SiO2, but the surface concentration (loading amount per surface area) was clearly high. More importantly, the used amount of ReO x species can be reduced to a quarter, and the Ir-ReO x interface which is the active site is efficiently formed on the TiO2 support with a limited amount of ReO x . The cost of Ir-ReO x catalysts can be decreased for their potential practical usage since both iridium and rhenium are expensive elements. It should be noted that Ir-ReO x /TiO2 catalyst as well as 20 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 was reusable in the glycerol hydrogenolysis under the optimized conditions. Table 2 summarizes the characterization results of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 and Ir-ReO x /TiO2. Small amount of ReO x species would be sublimated during the calcination at 773 K on the SiO2, and the loss of ReO x species became severe on the 20 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 since only one-third of ReO x species remained on the catalyst [ 33 ]. The similar loss of Re was also found on the TiO2. Decreasing the amount of Re would much suppress the sublimation, but the activity decreased due to the reduced number of active Ir-ReO x interfaces. The Ir particles seemed to be well dispersed on the SiO2 since the particles were slightly grown from 2.0 to 3.2 nm with Ir amount from 4 wt% to 20 wt%. On the TiO2, considering the same crystal structure (rutile type) of IrO2 and the support, Ir species can be anchored with high dispersion (~2.0 nm) even at very low surface area of rutile TiO2 [ 50 ]. The coverage of ReO x species on the Ir metal particles was around 50%–70% over Ir-ReO x -based catalysts at various amounts on the SiO2 or TiO2, where the uncovered Ir metal surface is accessible to H2 for activation. On the SiO2 support, Ir species can be fully reduced to metallic Ir0 whereas Ir δ+ species were present on the TiO2 as confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy due to the strong interaction between Ir and surface TiO x species. Higher temperature is necessary for Ir-ReO x /TiO2 catalysts to reduce most Ir species to metallic state. Moreover, the valence of ReO x species was almost constant at ~+3 regardless of Ir amount or support by XPS and XANES spectroscopy. However, the Re species on the 20 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 reduced in a liquid phase (water) with H2 at 473 K (L, 473) were at +1, which might be explained by the large Re amount leading to the higher reduction degree. Recently, Kondoh et al. [ 68 ] investigated the reduction behavior of submonolayer of Re species on an Ir(111) single-crystal (ResIr) by in-situ near-ambient- pressure XPS. After the reduction at 373 or 573 K, the main Re species was Re d+ (0 < d ≤ 1), and an OH group bridged between the Re d+ atoms. The amount of totally reduced Re0 atoms without bonded oxygen atom was very small. An important point is that the binding energies of this Re d+ and Re0 metal are similar, and sometimes both species were regarded as “Re0” in some other studies [ 69–71 ]. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis is powerful enough to provide direct evidence for understanding the interaction of Ir-ReO x pairs. It is difficult to distinguish between Ir and Re as a backscattering atom, and the bond is denoted by Re-Ir (or -Re). Generally, the coordination number of Re-Ir (or -Re) [CNRe-Ir (or -Re)] is almost unchanged when Re amount was optimized on the Ir/SiO2 and Ir/TiO2. It is characteristic that the CNRe-Ir (or -Re) increases from 6 to ~9 by increasing the amount of Ir to 20 wt% on the SiO2 or by the use of TiO2 as a support with decreasing the Re/Ir ratio (Table 3 ). This suggests that more ReO x species are interacted with Ir metal surface, and thus, the synergy between Ir particles and ReO x clusters can be enhanced by raising the Ir amount or employing TiO2 to disperse Ir-ReO x pairs. Compared with Ir-ReO x /SiO2, the CNRe-O becomes slightly smaller with the increase of Re-O bond length from 0.202 to 0.211–0.214 nm on the 20 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 and Ir-ReO x /TiO2, which indicates that the local coordination environment of ReO x species would be different on these two catalysts. It should be noted that the CNRe-Ir (or -Re) was unchanged for the fresh (reduced) and spent Ir-ReO x catalysts, which suggests that the local structures of ReO x clusters are stable during the reaction. Fig. 6 shows the TEM images and model structures of 4 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Re/Ir = 0.83, A), 20 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Re/Ir = 0.34, B), and 4 wt%-Ir Ir-ReO x /TiO2 (Re/Ir = 0.24, C). Increasing the amount of Ir or decreasing the surface area of support provides more opportunities to make Ir nanoparticles and ReO x clusters closely contacted, leading to the formation of high surface concentration of Ir-ReO x particles even at smaller ReO x amount. The proposed structure is further verified by the surface area occupied by one Ir-ReO x particle on the TiO2, where the value is calculated to be 9.6, and 16.2 nm2 per one particle for 4 wt%, and 2 wt% Ir-ReO x /TiO2 at the same Re/Ir ratio, respectively [ 50 ]. These mutually interacted Ir-ReO x particles give more interface sites between Ir and ReO x to increase the catalytic activity per total Ir or Re. In the grouping of Fig. 3, the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalysts are the typical type A catalysts, and the Ir-ReO x /TiO2 catalyst belongs to the type B. The use of support with very small surface area forces the connection between Ir and ReO x . 2.1.2 Direct hydrogenolysis mechanism The regioselective cleavage of secondary OH group in glycerol has been investigated on the based of kinetics in the glycerol hydrogenolysis over the Ir-ReO x catalysts. Table 4 lists the reaction orders with respect to glycerol concentration and H2 pressure. The reaction order on glycerol concentration was about 0–0.2, suggesting that most Ir-ReO x active sites are saturated with glycerol molecules. All the Ir-ReO x catalysts showed a first order on H2 pressure, indicating that one hydrogen species by H2 heterolytic dissociation (H2 → H+ + H–) was involved in the C–O bond cleavage. These results suggest that the reaction mechanism of glycerol hydrogenolysis is essentially the same over SiO2- and TiO2-supported Ir-ReO x catalysts. In order to confirm the active hydrogen species, 2-isopropoxyethanol was selected as a model (equation 1). The reaction result demonstrated the product ratio of ethanol to 2-propanol almost of 1, suggesting that hydride (H–) is the active species in selective dissociation of C–O bond neighboring to primary OH group by an SN2-type reaction [ 32 ]. (1) Similar reaction kinetics were also obtained using 1,2-PrD, erythritol, and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol as substrates with HO–CH2C(–O)– structure [ 48,67,72,73 ]. We propose the reaction mechanism of the C–O hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Ir-ReO x catalysts as shown in Fig. 7 : glycerol is adsorbed on the surface of the ReO x cluster by the terminal OH group; H2 is heterolytically dissociated at the Ir-ReO x interface to give the proton and hydride species; hydride attack on the Re-O–C–C–O– with anti-conformation around the C–C bond dissociates the C–O bond (rate determining step, r.d.s); finally, 1,3-PrD is released from the catalyst surface and the Ir-ReO x interface is regenerated. This direct hydrogenolysis mechanism has been also proposed for the Rh-MO x /SiO2 catalysts (M = Re and Mo) for hydrogenolysis of 1,2-PrD and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to 1-PrOH and 1,5-pentanediol, respectively [ 35,45,74 ]. However, in the glycerol hydrogenolysis, the products over Rh-MO x /SiO2 catalysts are mixture of PrDs and PrOHs [ 35,44 ]. 2.1.3 Other proposed reaction mechanisms for Ir-ReOx catalysts Some studies employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to discuss the reaction mechanism in the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-PrD. Mushrif and co-workers proposed that the primary hydroxyl group on the ReO x cluster to form a 2,3-dihydroxypropoxide is energetic favorable and r.d.s is the C–O cleavage of the secondary hydroxyl group in the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-PrD [ 75 ], which is consistent with our direct mechanism. On the other hand, they proposed that Brønsted acidic ReO x species favored a protonation-dehydration mechanism (Fig. 8(A) ). The activation barriers for removal of secondary hydroxyl group in the two different mechanisms are 165.2 kJ mol–1 (direct mechanism) and 123.3 kJ mol–1 (protonation and dehydration mechanism), respectively, which are clearly lower, although still large, than the corresponding activation barriers for removal of primary hydroxyl with 217.9 and 167.7 kJ mol–1. This result agrees well with the obtained selectivity pattern that 1,3-PrD is preferentially formed other than 1,2-PrD over the Ir-ReO x catalyst [ 32,33,48,50 ]. It seems that the protonation and dehydration mechanism is more energetic favorable, but the concerted hydride attack in our proposed direct mechanism cannot be ruled out since active hydrogen related species are not taken into consideration. The real system uses water solvent, which may also much affect the acidity of catalyst surface and mechanism. They further suggested that the promoting effect of H2SO4 was increasing the local concentration of glycerol within the silica pores rather than altering the reaction pathways or energetics. This is also consistent with our findings that H2SO4 was not directly involved in the hydrogenolysis reaction, but it can affect the stability of Ir-ReO x active interface [ 32,33 ]. Zhou et al. [ 76 ] proposed a similar dehydration-hydrogenation mechanism over Ir-Re alloy catalyst. The formation of H2O* from H* species on Ir site and OH* from scission of the βC–OH bond on Re metal site is regarded as the r.d.s (Fig. 8(B)). A promoting effect of solid acids was also observed using Amberlyst-15 or HZSM-5 as an additive over Ir-Re alloy catalyst. However, the addition of H2SO4 much suppressed the glycerol hydrogenolysis on the Ir-Re/SiO2 catalyst, which shows a totally opposite trend to the hydrogenolysis reactions that were enhanced by H2SO4 on the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 [ 32,75 ]. The negative effect was ascribed to the coverage of SO4 2– anion on the Ir-Re site, which suppresses the adsorption of glycerol. Unfortunately, the reaction kinetics and the characterizations for catalyst after usage are not fully studied, and further investigation is still desirable. 2.1.4 Ir-FeOx catalysts: Novel selectivity in the hydrogenolysis of 1,2-PrD The hydrogenolysis of 1,2-PrD by selective removal of primary OH group has not been achieved before, and 1-PrOH is the main product over the Ir-ReO x catalysts (Fig. 9 ) [ 32,33 ]. Very recently, we found that the Ir particles modified with FeO x species supported on the TiO2 [ 36 ] and boron nitride (BN) [ 37 ] enabled the conversion of 1,2-PrD to 2-PrOH with high selectivity. The TiO2 support was the same one for the Ir-ReO x /TiO2 catalyst mentioned above: rutile structure and very small surface area. The Ir-FeO x catalysts are less active than Ir-ReO x ones and require significantly higher temperature. Fe species are rather poisonous for the Ir-ReO x catalysts, and this behavior is related to the low selectivity of Ir-FeO x catalysts toward the removal of primary OH group. 2-PrOH was selectively obtained at the initial stage over both Irc-r-FeO x /TiO2 (c-r defined as Ir/TiO2 after calcination, reduction, and further introduction of FeO x species) [ 36 ] and Ir-FeO x /BN catalysts [ 37 ], for which the calcination and reduction steps before introduction of FeO x species were omitted (Table 5 ). The highest 2-PrOH yield was 53% over Irc-r-FeO x /TiO2. The 2-PrOH yield from glycerol was decreased to 30%, because the selective hydrogenolysis at the primary C–O group should be carried out twice. 2.1.5 Structures and reaction schemes of Ir-Fe(Ox) catalysts The Ir-FeO x /support catalysts have been also characterized in detail. The characterization results of Ir-FeO x catalysts are summarized in Table 6 . For Ir-FeO x /TiO2, the TEM-EDX analysis showed that bimetallic particles almost fully covered the support particles (Fig. 10(A) ) [ 36 ], in a similar manner to Ir-ReO x /TiO2. The morphology of Ir-FeO x /BN is much different from TiO2-supported catalyst (Fig. 10(B)): two-dimensional bimetallic nanodendrites were formed on the BN support [ 37 ]. Rather than the limitation of the support surface area, weak interaction between FeO x and BN support can give the bimetallic structure (type A in Fig. 3). An important difference between Ir-ReO x and Ir-FeO x catalysts is that Fe species form alloy, while Re species in Ir-ReO x are mainly two-dimensional Re species with OH groups formed on Ir particle surface. In the active catalysts with appropriate Fe/Ir ratio (Fe/Ir = 0.25), the Fe species were deeply reduced, and about 70% of Fe species were estimated to be in the metallic state. In Fe K-edge EXAFS, the CNFe-O was small, while about 30% of Fe species were still in oxidized states. For metallic bonds, only Fe–Ir was observed without Fe–Fe. From these results, Ir-Fe alloy was regarded as the major Fe species in the active Ir-FeO x catalysts [ 36,37 ]. The reduction degree of FeO x species was clearly higher on the BN support with the small CN (0.4) of Fe–O, compared to TiO2, while the catalytic activity was comparable to each other. Therefore, Ir-Fe alloy was regarded as the major active site. The Fe-rich Irc-r-FeO x /TiO2 (Fe/Ir = 1) catalyst, which is almost inactive, also contained alloyed Fe0 [ 36 ]; however, the majority of the Fe species were oxidized ones. The excess oxidized Fe species can block the active site to decrease the activity. The kinetic study over Irc-r-FeO x /TiO2 and Ir-FeO x /BN was performed for the hydrogenolysis of 1,2-BuD, and a first reaction order on H2 pressure was obtained over both catalysts. It is assumed that reaction order on H2 pressure would not be altered since 1,2-PrD and 1,2-BuD have a similar structure of 1,2-alkanediol. Therefore, similar to the Ir-ReO x catalysts, the direct hydrogenolysis mechanism is proposed in the 1,2-PrD hydrogenolysis, where hydride attack is the r.d.s. However, the adsorption modes of 1,2-PrD on Ir-FeO x are different from that on Ir-ReO x surface. 1,2-PrD is relatively easy to form alkoxide species by dissociative adsorption of primary OH group on the interfacial ReO x sites. In contrast, 1,2-PrD is more likely adsorbed as alcohol instead of alkoxide by coordinating with the Ir-Fe surface (Fig. 11 ) [ 36 ]. Both primary and secondary C–OH groups are adsorbed as alcohol, and the more accessible primary C–OH group is attacked by the hydride species. Further modification with Mo species (Mo/Ir = 0.08) combined with high loading amount was reported as an effective strategy to highly enhance the activity of Ir-FeO x /BN catalyst (~25-fold) with the retention of the regioselectivity pattern [ 51 ]. Both the formation of condensed nanostructures (~2 nm) exposing more active sites and the formation of trimetallic alloy (Ir-Fe-Mo) were clarified as the key factors of high activity of the trimetallic catalyst (Ir-Fe0.13-Mo0.08/BN (20 wt% Ir)), which was in-situ formed on the BN under mild conditions (≤ 453 K). Typically, alloying early transition metal (M') with noble metal (M) is not easy, and M' is mainly present in the form of oxide (M-M'O x ). The in-situ formation of Mo-involved alloy on the BN under mild conditions as highly efficient promoter is, therefore, exceptional. 2.2 Pt-WOx catalysts 2.2.1 Development and selectivity patterns Most Pt catalysts for HDO of polyols including glycerol have been combined with WO x species, and the target product is 1,3-PrD. Pt-WO x catalysts are generally less active than Ir-ReO x ones (lower average rate even at higher reaction temperature), but with optimized catalysts higher yield of 1,3-PrD can be obtained. Nevertheless, the selectivity of Pt-WO x catalysts much depends on the selection of components and composition, and very limited papers reported high 1,3-PrD yields. The application of Pt-WO x catalysts to other substrates (described in the next section) has been further limited in comparison with Ir-ReO x catalysts. Pt-WO x catalysts were reported to be effective in the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-PrD earlier than Ir-ReO x catalysts. In 2007, Suzuki et al. [ 77 ] of KAO Corporation described in their patent that Pt-WO x /Al2O3 (5 wt% for both Pt and W) catalyzed 23% conversion of glycerol with 67% selectivity to 1,3-PrD at 433 K and 5 MPa of H2 in a water solvent. Dam et al. [ 78 ] investigated acidic additives of tungstic acid (heterogeneous), phosphotungstic acid (homogeneous; HPW), and silicotungstic acid (homogeneous; HSiW) in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol over commercial 5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 and 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalysts. Glycerol can be converted over both catalyst (~40% and ~10% conversion on Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/SiO2), but 1,2-PrD together with degradation products were mainly produced without formation of 1,3-PrD at 473 K, 4 MPa of H2 in water. The addition of the aforementioned acids less affected the conversion, and even a negative effect was observed over the combination of phosphotungstic acid and Pt/Al2O3. The 1,3-PrD selectivity reached 49% at the conversion of 28% over Pt/Al2O3 + HSiW, and the performance exceeded that using a tungstic acid additive. Accordingly, HSiW was the optimum additive to promote the target reaction. However, the catalytic performance was difficult to be further improved by adjusting the acid or glycerol concentrations, and the system suffered from the poor reusability due to sintering of Pt species. Brønsted acid sites are regarded as active sites for the elimination of secondary OH group in glycerol according to many studies including recent ones [ 27 ]. These results using homogeneous acids showed that the chemistry is not simple. The interaction between Pt sites and WO x species should be considered. For the practical viewpoint, well-designed catalysts containing both Pt and WO x species without use of homogeneous promoters are desirable. Many works for Pt-WO x catalysts including the first effective one by KAO corporation mentioned above used simple supports such as Al2O3 and ZrO2 [ 22,27 ]. The Pt/WO3/ZrO2 (10–30 wt% W) catalysts can be prepared by impregnating a W precursor solution with ZrO2 and calcination, and subsequently impregnating with a Pt precursor solution and calcination. The 1,3-PrD yield cannot exceed 35% regardless of fixed-bed or batch reactors [ 39,79,80 ]. Zong et al. [ 56 ] prepared Pt/ZrO2 by an impregnation method and further used it to impregnate with HSiW solution to obtain the Pt-WO x /ZrO2 (1.9 wt% Pt, ~7.6 wt% W) catalyst, and the effect of crystal phases of ZrO2 was also investigated. Tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2)-supported Pt-WO x catalyst gave better performance of 76.2% conversion and 64.8% selectivity to 1,3-PrD relative to 36.4% conversion and 33.8% selectivity at 413 K and 8 MPa over the monoclinic ZrO2-supported catalyst. Kaneda et al. [ 52 ] employed boehmite (AlOOH) as a support to prepare Pt/WO x /AlOOH (1.8 wt% Pt, 8 wt% W) with an excellent 1,3-PrD yield at 66%–69%, which had been the highest value among all catalysts for the glycerol hydrogenolysis until 2022. The catalyst was obtained by introducing WO x onto AlOOH by an ion-exchange method, and then WO x /AlOOH was impregnated with H2PtCl6 solution by the vaporization method. The phase of support was reversibly changed between boehmite and γ-Al2O3 by calcination and hydration, and the structure of tungsten species can be also changed accordingly. The high performance was thought to be the active Al-OH species working as anchoring sites for glycerol adsorption. Alumina can be also used as a support to prepare Pt/WO x /Al2O3 catalysts, but the catalytic performances are not beyond Pt/WO x /AlOOH. For example, the optimized Pt/WO x /Al2O3 (9 wt% Pt, 8 wt% W) afforded 53% conversion with 52% selectivity to 1,3-PrD at 473 K and 4.5 MPa [ 81 ]. Moreover, the structures of WO x species on the Al2O3 would be altered at different amounts such as monotungstate at 1 wt%–4 wt%, mono- and polytungstates coexistence at 7.5 wt%–12.9 wt%, polytungstates at 20.4 wt%, and nanoclusters at 30.8 wt% as verified by Raman spectroscopy [ 82 ]. The catalysts mentioned above have large W loading amount. The necessity of large loading can be explained by the weak interaction between WO x species and Pt (type B in Fig. 3), and the interaction between Pt and WO x was created by saturating the WO x species on the support surface. Another approach to creating the interaction between Pt and WO x is the use of supports containing W in the lattice. An extreme method is the direct deposition of Pt particles onto tungsten oxides, namely Pt/WO x [ 55,83 ]. Zhang et al. [ 54 ] found that Pt species (2 wt%) were dispersed as single/pseudo-single atom on the meso-WO x , showing 60% conversion and 36% selectivity to 1,3-PrD at 413 K and low H2 pressure of 1 MPa. The addition of Al (0.2 wt%) improved the catalytic performance of Pt/WO3, which gave 90% conversion and 44% selectivity to 1,3-PrD over Pt-AlO x /WO3 at 453 K and 3 MPa [ 55 ]. However, the performance of these catalysts, especially selectivity, was not sufficient. The surface of WO3 itself is not suitable as a selective catalyst for this reaction. For catalysts using W-containing support, Zong et al. [ 57 ] incorporated WO x into mesoporous SBA-15 by the sol-gel method, and then the obtained W-SBA-15 was impregnated with a Pt precursor to fix Pt amount at 3 wt%. A high selectivity to 1,3-PrD of 70.8% at high glycerol conversion of 86.8% with the W/Si atomic ratio of 1/640 distinguished this catalyst from the other Pt-WO x catalysts, considering the small amount of tungsten oxide. WO x species exited as monotungstate on the SBA-15, and the strong synergy between Pt nanoparticles and monotungstate favored the formation of Brønsted acid sites for selective cleavage of secondary OH group. By the similar catalyst preparation method, a series of effective Pt-WO x catalysts with a small amount of W but strong mutual interaction was successfully synthesized. Pt/WO x /Beta (Si/Al = 13 wt%, 1.5 wt% Pt, 0.5 wt% W) afforded a conversion of 84.2% with 1,3-PrD selectivity of 46.1% at 413 K and 5 MPa [ 84 ]; Pt/W-MCFs (W-doped siliceous mesostructured cellular foams, 3 wt% Pt, Si/W = 316) showed a high yield of 1,3-PrD at 63% was achieved over the optimized catalyst at 423 K and 4 MPa [ 85 ], and Pt/WO x /α-Al2O3 (2 wt% Pt, 0.4 wt% W) gave a conversion of 51.7% with 1,3-PrD selectivity of 45.7% at 453 K and 5 MPa [ 86 ]. Although the interaction between Pt and WO x can be enhanced even with a small W amount, the rate for the 1,3-PrD production is not significantly improved (Table 1). It might be explained by the fact that the smaller W amount makes Pt species less available to be interacted. An effective approach is to use a support with small S BET, which is similar to the case of rutile TiO2 and BN as support for Ir-ReO x and Ir-FeO x based catalysts (see above). Owing to this feature, T-Ta2O5- [ 58 ] and Nb14W3O44-supported [ 59 ] Pt-WO x catalysts with S BET about 10 m2 g–1 showed clearly higher Pt-based average rate for the 1,3-PrD production than the other Pt-WO x catalysts since most Pt species were supposed to strongly interact with WO x species even at a small amount of W. Liu et al. [ 58 ] deposited WO x species onto T-Ta2O5, and Pt species (0.68 wt%) were positively charged over the modified WO x /T-Ta2O5 (0.51 wt% W, Fig. 12(A) ). In contrast to metallic Pt0/WO x /T-Ta2O5, the 1,3-PrD yield was about two-fold higher than Pt δ+/WO x /T-Ta2O5 under the same reaction conditions (87% conversion with 46% selectivity to 1,3-PrD at 433 K and 5 MPa), which was ascribed to the Pt δ+–O–W interface. They suggested that the glycerol adsorption and H2 dissociation were promoted on the single Pt δ+ site, and the in-situ generated Brønsted acid sites of W–(OH)–Ta by H δ+ spillover favored the elimination of secondary OH group. Since the loading amount of both Pt and W are quite low, such strong interaction between Pt and WO x can be due to the small surface area of T-Ta2O5. Very recently, Wang et al. [ 59 ] synthesized a novel support of Nb14W3O44 by a sol-gel method, and they used it to disperse Pt species (3 wt%). It should be noted that Pt/Nb2O5 could catalyze the glycerol hydrogenolysis (52% conversion with 32% selectivity to 1,3-PrD), which might be due to the synergetic effect between Pt and NbO x species [ 87,88 ]. The yield of 1,3-PrD became higher (90% conversion with 49% selectivity to 1,3-PrD) by the addition of WO3 onto the Pt/Nb2O5 (Pt/WO3/Nb2O5; Nb/W = 14/3); however, the similar selectivity was observed for Pt/WO3. On the other hand, an unprecedented high selectivity of 77% to 1,3-PrD at the high glycerol conversion of 93% over the Pt/Nb14W3O44 using the novel support under the same reaction conditions was found. Under the optimized conditions, the 1,3-PrD yield over Pt/Nb14W3O44 reached 75.2%, which is the highest reported value so far. The Raman spectrum showed a new sharp band at 692 cm–1 over Pt/Nb14W3O44, which was assigned to the W–O–Nb bond by the interactive coordination of WO6 and NbO6 octahedra in the lattice. The W–O–Nb structure was important for the activation of secondary C–O bond in glycerol, and those interfacial Pt species at the Pt-WO x sites activated H2 molecules (Fig. 12(B)), which accounted for the excellent performance in the glycerol hydrogenolysis. It can be concluded that the strong affinity of Pt and WO x species efficiently promoted the glycerol conversion into 1,3-PrD, and the Pt-WO x interface benefits from the small S BET of support in some cases. 2.2.2 Construction of Pt-WOx interface on the conventional SiO2 support Most Pt-WO x catalysts with good 1,3-PrD selectivity used designed supports to enhance the interaction between Pt and WO x ; however, the preparation of such catalysts in a large scale as industrial catalysts is rather difficult. We found that a conventional SiO2 support can be used to construct the interfacial Pt-WO x active sites even with a small amount of W. The local coordination environment of WO x species on the Pt/SiO2 was drastically different when increasing the amount of tungsten oxide by a simple impregnation method [ 89 ]. As verified by curve fitting results of W L 3-edge EXAFS spectra, the CN of W-Pt (or -W) gradually decreased from 5.5 to 2.4 (Table 7 ). Combined with XANES spectra and XPS results, WO x species tended to alloy with Pt at smaller amount, interacted with Pt particle surface, and to be polymerized with increasing W amounts. The average valence of W for the optimized Pt-WO x /SiO2 (4 wt% Pt, W/Pt = 0.25) was about +4, suggesting the partial reduction of WO x species. The volcano type dependency of glycerol hydrogenolysis activity on the W amounts was found (Fig. 13 ), whereas the catalytic performance showed no direct relationship with acid sites on the catalysts. The WO x species interacted with Pt particles were suggested to be present between Pt particles and SiO2 because most WO x species were undetectable by XPS analysis. The formation of such structure can be explained by the weaker interaction between Pt and SiO2 than that between Pt and WO x (type C in Fig. 3). In general, the interaction of M and M'O x becomes stronger when M'O x is partially reduced. However, the reduction of WO x to below +5 valence has been rarely reported. The deeper reduction of WO x on SiO2 than that on other supports, in combination with relatively weak interaction between Pt and SiO2, can give this unique structure. Similarly, the strong affinity between WO x and Pt on SiO2 was also proposed by Ma and co-workers, although the optimum W/Pt ratio was 0.5 wt% at 4 wt% of Pt [ 90 ]. The highest 1,3-PrD yield over our Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst reached 57% at the full glycerol conversion at 413 K and 8 MPa over Pt-WO x /SiO2 (4 wt% Pt, 0.9 wt% W, W/Pt = 0.25). This Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst gives the sufficiently high yield of 1,3-PrD, although not the highest among all the reported systems (Table 1). The main by-product was 1-PrOH during the glycerol hydrogenolysis over Pt-WO x /SiO2, and the overhydrogenolysis of target 1,3-PrD produced 1-PrOH instead of propane [ 61 ]. This character distinguishes Pt-WO x catalysts from Ir-ReO x catalysts in other polyols valorization as discussed in later section. 2.2.3 Reaction mechanisms WO x species are generally regarded as Brønsted acid sites on the Pt-WO x catalysts, which favors the cleavage of secondary OH group in glycerol via an acid-catalyzed E1 mechanism (Fig. 14 ) [ 27,52,54,56,57,81,91,92 ]. H2 participated in the later step by either homolytic dissociation or heterolytic dissociation [ 27,52,54,56,57,81,91 ]. However, direct evidence study for such mechanism is quite limited. Moreover, the kinetic study for most Pt-WO x catalysts is insufficient since the reaction mechanism is closely related to reaction conditions. The dependency of H2 pressure on the glycerol hydrogenolysis varies over Pt-WO x catalysts, for example, positive reaction order for Pt-WO x /SiO2 [ 90 ], volcano-type dependencies on H2 pressure for Pt/WO3/TiO2/SiO2 [ 93 ], and even negative reaction order for Pt/WO x [ 54 ]. Besides the effect of reaction order on H2 pressure, it should be noted that the same reduction degree of WO x species is the prerequisite to discuss the kinetics. Allgeier et al. [ 92 ] employed the deuterium incorporation in HDO of 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PeD) that has a similar structure with 1,2-PrD over Pt-WO x /TiO2. The kinetic isotope effect (KIE) was initially investigated by using H2/H2O and D2/D2O systems. The ratio of rate constant (k H/k D) of 0.84 ± 0.11 was obtained, which disproved the direct C–O bond cleavage mechanism in which the formation of C–H bond was expected to be involved in the r.d.s with a primary KIE. They further excluded the isotope exchange from 1,2-PeD using different gas/solvent systems, although small extent of exchanged isotope was observed between 1,2-PeD and solvent. Deuterium incorporation using D2/H2O and H2/D2O (Table 8 ) for 1,2-PeD HDO showed a significant incorporation of isotopes from the solvent rather than the gas in the product, which can be resulted from the much faster isotope exchange between active hydrogen species and water solvent. Then, a plausible mechanism via an enol intermediate was proposed. However, this mechanism cannot explain our results in the hydrogenolysis of 1,3-butanediol (1,3-BuD) that the ratio of 2-butanol (2-BuOH) to 1-BuOH was 4 over Pt-WO x /SiO2 [ 60 ]. Accordingly, a different mechanism should be included for explaining the selectivity patterns for HDO of substrate like 1,3-BuD. 2.3 Ru-based bimetallic catalysts 2.3.1 Ru-ReOx catalysts Supported monometallic Ru catalysts are much more active than Pt, Rh and Pd catalysts in the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PrD [ 94 ]. However, C–C bond dissociation products such as ethylene glycol (EG), ethanol, methanol, and methane were co-produced even at initial stage [ 94–96 ]. Earlier studies (2005–2010) showed that the combination of Ru/C catalyst and Amberlyst as a solid acid greatly enhanced the catalytic performance, activity and selectivity to 1,2-PrD [ 62,94,95 ] because of the promoting effect of acid-catalyzing dehydration and hydrogenation on Ru site, while degradation products were largely produced. In 2008, Ma et al. [ 97 ] reported the effect of the Re2(CO)10 addition into Al2O3-, ZrO2-, and C-supported Ru catalysts, and found a significant promoting effect. More importantly, the production of EG via cleavage of C–C bond directly from glycerol was much inhibited. In order to combine the two components on the one catalyst, the same group prepared a series of supported Ru-ReO x catalysts via the impregnation with a mixture of RuCl3·4H2O and HReO4 solution [ 96 ]. It was found that ReO x species promoted the dispersion of Ru particles on the SiO2 and ZrO2, and the conversions were even higher compared to the combination of supported monometallic Ru catalysts and Re2(CO)10. However, the structure for such catalyst was not well elucidated. After 2010, the studies for Ru-based catalysts for the glycerol hydrogenolysis became limited because of the increasing attention on Ir- and Pt-based catalysts with higher chemo-selectivity (C–C dissociation is suppressed) and selective production of more valuable 1,3-PrD. Recently, the catalytic chemistry on biomass conversion has much expanded, such as pursuing new reactions with novel catalysts. The potential of Ru as a hydrogenolysis catalysts has been now deeply investigated again. We prepared bimetallic Ru-ReO x /SiO2 catalysts by a co-impregnation method, and the catalysts were applied to the HDO of 1,2-PrD. The presence of Re-Ru and Re-O bonds over Ru-ReO x /SiO2 (Table 9 ) suggested that ReO x species directly interacted with the Ru metal surface (type A catalyst in Fig. 3) [ 98 ]. The CN of Re-Re drastically increased from 2.1 to 8.0 when the Re/Ru ratio was doubled. It can be explained by the formation of Re metal particles, which was verified by EDX analysis (Figs. 15(A) and (B) ). Accordingly, the average valence of ReO x species was between +1–+2, which was lower than that of ReO x species on the Ir-ReO x catalysts at similar Ir amount. It should be noted that the Re metals were inactive sites whereas those ReO x species interacted with Ru particles were catalytically active. Owning to the strong synergy between Ru and ReO x species, the degradation products were remarkably decreased, where a 23% yield of 2-PrOH with a very high ratio of 2-PrOH/1-PrOH (> 20) was obtained over Ru-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst (5 wt% Ru, Re/Ru = 0.5) at 413 K and 8 MPa using 1,2-PrD as substrate [ 98 ]. Although such yield is lower than those given by the Ir-FeO x catalysts, it outperformed other Ru catalysts at that time [ 94,96,99 ]. Kinetic study gave a reaction order on H2 pressure of about +1 over the Ru-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst, suggesting the direct hydrogenolysis mechanism, which is basically the same as the mechanism over Ir-ReO x catalysts where hydride attack is the r.d.s. 1,2-PrD is relatively easy to form alkoxide species by the dissociative adsorption of primary OH group on the interfacial ReO x sites, and subsequent hydride attack to afford 2-PrOH and 1-PrOH (Fig. 16 ). 2.3.2 Ru-MoOx and Ru-WOx catalysts MoO x and WO x species were less reducible than ReO x on Ru metal particles, but strong affinity between them and Ru site has been proposed in other catalytic reduction systems [ 100–102 ]. The C–C bond dissociation could also be suppressed by the addition of MoO x [ 64 ] and WO x [ 65 ] into Ru nanoparticles, although the activity enhancement in glycerol conversion is not as remarkable as the addition of Re. Cai et al. [ 64 ] reported that the carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-supported Ru-MoO x catalysts could much decrease the selectivity to EG, leading to the formation of 1,2-PrD and 1-PrOH with the Mo amount from 1 wt% to 7 wt% at a fixed Ru amount of 2 wt%. Furthermore, the addition of phosphotungstic acid (HPW) drastically increased the 1,3-PrD selectivity from 15% to 38% at a similar conversion of 47% over Ru-MoO x /CNTs and Ru-MoO x /CNTs + HPW, respectively. HPW worked as Brønsted acid sites for the activation of secondary OH group via a 3-hydroxypropanal intermediate, and subsequent hydrogenation to obtain 1,3-PrD. On the other hand, Lewis acid sites originated from MoO x species and HPW catalyzed the dehydration and Ru catalyzed the hydrogenation to give 1,2-PrD. Carbon-supported Ru-WO x catalyst demonstrates much higher selectivity to 1,2-PrD than MoO x - or ReO x -modified Ru catalysts. The selectivity to 1,2-PrD was above 97% at 393–423 K at the glycerol conversion increasing from 45% to 70% under 0.5 MPa H2 over the optimized Ru-WO x /C (5 wt% Ru, 2 wt% W) [ 65 ]. In contrast, monometallic Ru/C gave the major product of EG, and WO x /C had no activity in the glycerol conversion, which pointed to the strong synergy between Ru and WO x species. CO adsorption showed that the dispersion of Ru particles was reduced from 15% to 7% upon the increase in the WO x amounts from 0.5 wt% to 2 wt%. The total acid amount determined by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) over the optimum bimetallic catalyst (2 wt% W) was remarkably higher than the cases of carbon support or catalysts with smaller W amounts. The result can explain the effect of H2 pressure that the glycerol conversion drastically increased at 0.2–0.5 MPa and became unchanged at higher pressure. Therefore, the steps involving H2 were not included in the r.d.s. Selva et al. [ 65 ] proposed the dehydration + hydrogenation mechanism (Fig. 17 ). Glycerol was activated on the WO x site with a primary OH group to be dehydrated into prop-2-ene-1,2-diol. This intermediate was successively hydrogenated by active hydrogen species from Ru site to release 1,2-PrD. However, 1,3-PrD, a common by-product catalyzed by acid sites in glycerol hydrogenolysis over Ru-based catalysts, was not detected at all. They excluded the effect of Na content in the carbon support, but other impurities might disturb the system [ 103 ], for example, some other metal species. 2.4 Notes for elucidation of relationship between structure and performance The strong mutual interaction in the bimetallic catalysts has been recognized, although it remains a great challenge to efficiently construct those interfacial sites. The use of characterization techniques such as TEM, XRD, CO adsorption, CO FT-IR, XPS and XAFS can provide detailed information to elucidate the potential structure of catalysts. However, ex-situ characterization results might not reflect the true active sites under working conditions, considering that HDO reactions are performed under high H2 pressure and high temperature. In particular, XPS is well known to be very sensitive to the handling of samples, and the spectra obtained for air-exposed samples are useless in the discussion of electronic state of the catalysts during the reaction. For XPS and XAFS, the measurement of reduced catalysts must be carried out without exposure to air during collecting and handling. TEM and XRD are generally not sensitive to the environment, and the measurement is usually carried out under air or after exposed to air. However, it is necessary to keep in mind that the catalyst structure might be changed by the oxidation with air; for example, Re species is easily oxidized and re-dispersed by air, and the oxygen vacancies in the oxide support may be easily filled with oxygen or water under air [ 104–106 ]. The development of in-situ characterization techniques is of much significance to understand the local coordination environment of metal and metal oxide during catalysis. Moreover, the role of acidic ReO x , MoO x , and WO x species is still unclear whether such species work as the adsorption sites, provide Brønsted acidity, or interact with noble metal for synergistic catalysis. The solvent, usually water, can also much affect the properties including acidity of oxide species. In addition, homolytic dissociation of H2 is widely accepted over supported metal nanoparticles [ 107,108 ], but it cannot explain the kinetics of Ir-ReO x catalysts in the glycerol hydrogenolysis. One possible explanation is that the heterolytic H2 dissociation over Ir particles is promoted by ReO x species since rich defect sites on the ReO x species are suggested to facilitate heterolytic H2 dissociation [ 109 ]. However, the detection of hydride species has not been achieved and thus direct evidence is lacking. The deep understanding of catalyst structure would also be beneficial to elucidate reaction mechanism because the absence of spectator metal species makes it easier to identify the active site. 3 Application of bimetallic catalysts in HDO of biomass derivatives and polymers 3.1 Partial HDO of biomass-derived polyols and ethers Erythritol is commercially accessible by fermentation and regarded as a potential C4 platform chemical in biomass refinery [ 110 ]. Although the structure of erythritol is similar with glycerol, intramolecular dehydration [ 111 ] and isomerization [ 112 ] make its reaction much more complex. While the target product is frequently a specific butanediol, diols also have high reactivity toward HDO, which would also decrease the selectivity to the target diol. Table 10 lists the performances of bimetallic catalysts in the erythritol HDO. Ir-ReO x catalysts gave 1,4-BuD as a main product via the hydrogenolysis of erythritol to 1,2,4-butanetriol (1,2,4-BuT) and successive C–O bond cleavage of 1,2,4-BuT to 1,4-BuD (Fig. 18 ) [ 113 ]. Overhydrogenolysis would produce 1-BuOH with undetectable C–C bond dissociation products. The higher rate over the TiO2-supported catalyst can be explained by the unique structure with the more interfacial Ir-ReO x sites. Sad et al. [ 114 ] investigated the effect of support on the HDO of erythritol over Ir-ReO x catalysts. They also found that TiO2 (P25)-supported Ir-ReO x catalyst showed higher activity than those using SiO2, CeO2, Al2O3, and ZrO2 as supports, and the maximum BuDs yield was 53% at 473 K and 2.5 MPa. The same group also calculated the apparent activation energy for the HDO of erythritol over the Ir-ReO x /TiO2 (P25) catalyst, and the apparent activation energy of the C–O hydrogenolysis (79 kJ mol–1) was clearly lower than that of C–C hydrogenolysis (133 kJ mol–1) and dehydration (212 kJ mol–1) [ 115 ]. In the case of Pt-WO x catalysts, the reaction route was the same as the Ir-ReO x catalysts, and the overhydrogenolysis less occurred to give a higher 1,4-BuD yield. Pt-WO x /SiO2 afforded a 1,4-BuD yield of 54%, which is the highest value to date [ 61 ]. Under severe conditions, the main product became 1-BuOH, which the overhydrogenolysis product of 1,4-BuD. The selectivity pattern indicates that primary OH group in diols is less reactive over Pt-WO x catalysts compared to Ir-ReO x catalysts. For the Ir-FeO x catalysts, the regioselective character enables the cleavage of primary OH group to form 1,2,3-BuT, followed by hydrogenolysis of C–O bond at 1-position to produce 2,3-BuD, and the yields were about 30% [ 36,37,51 ]. It should be noted that 2-BuOH was the main product in the 1,3-BuD hydrogenolysis (83% yield over Irc-r-FeO x /TiO2) [ 36 ], which is similar with the Pt-WO x catalyst. The selectivity of specific diol over Ru-ReO x and Rh-ReO x catalysts was low, and a mixture of diols was generally obtained [ 69,116,117 ]. Wang et al. [ 118 ] used a fixed-bed reactor to perform the HDO of erythritol over Ru-MoO x /Mo2C, and gaseous products were largely produced (33% yield) with a yield of 22% and 16% to 1-BuOH and 2-BuOH, respectively. 1,4-Anhydroerythritol (1,4-AHERY) is easy to obtain by the dehydration of erythritol. The C–O bond dissociation in the ring is a prerequisite to obtain alkanediols or mono-alcohols. 1,3-BuD was successfully synthesized by using the Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst, on which 1,2,3-BuT was produced by ring-opening, followed by selective removal of secondary OH group to give 1,3-BuD [ 61 ]. A high yield of 1,3-BuD (54%) was achieved with a major by-product of 2-BuOH. On the other hand, MoO x -, WO x -, and ReO x -modified Rh/SiO2 catalysts were highly active and selective to 2-BuOH, and Rh-MoO x /SiO2 showed the highest yield of 51% [ 120 ]. The formation of 2-BuOH was related to the high reactivity of 1,3-BuD and 1,2-BuD, and the HDO process might include the successive C–O hydrogenolysis by the desorption of intermediates and multiple C–O hydrogenolysis without desorption of intermediates. Xylitol is a typical C5 sugar alcohol, and its partial HDO can afford pentanols (PeOHs, Table 11 ); however, the production of C5 diols with high selectivity has not yet been achieved. The combination of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 with HZSM-5 in the presence of a mixture of n-dodecane and water as solvent was found to be effective to obtain PeOHs [ 49 ]. The addition of HZSM-5 was necessary to stabilize the interfacial ReOH species, like the case of glycerol HDO. The lower yield of 1-PeOH than 2-/3-PeOHs was due to the higher reactivity of 1-PeOH during the HDO process, which was evaluated by the competitive hydrogenolysis of PeOHs mixture. With regard to the Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst, the selectivity pattern was different from that over the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst. The yield decreased in the order of 1-PeOH (30%) > 3-PeOH (20%) > 2-PeOH (9%) [ 61 ]. The acidic WO x /SiO2 catalyzed the dehydration of xylitol to 1,4-anhydroxylitol, whereas Pt-WO x /SiO2 at the same WO x amount promoted the C–O hydrogenolysis reactions. The scheme for producing each compound is shown Fig. 19 . The high yield of 1-PeOH can be ascribed to the low reactivity of primary OH group on the Pt-WO x /SiO2. This catalyst would gradually lose activity due to the coverage of the active sites by coke, and the calcination at mild temperature (573 K) can remove the carbonaceous species, which improves the reusability of Pt-WO x /SiO2. Ru-MoO x /Mo2C also gave the major product of 1-PeOH, but the yields of total PeOHs were lower than those by the Pt-WO x /SiO2 catalyst. In addition, Ru/MnO x /C mainly produced glycols and glycerol by C–C cleavage reactions. Furthermore, probably due to the weak interaction between Ru and MnO x species, a large amount of MnO x species were detected in the reaction solution [ 121 ]. We have extended the substrate to xylan, which is a kind of hemicellulose abundant in wood, and used Ir-ReO x /SiO2 as a variant of the HDO reaction. With the H2SO4 additive as a promoter, xylan can be converted into 3-/2-PeOHs with their total yield of 32%, whereas 1-PeOH was further transformed into n-pentane by overhydrogenolysis. The hydrogenolysis of sorbitol has been widely investigated, although the main products are usually C2 and C3 compounds [ 123 ]. We investigated the performance of SiO2-supported Ir-ReO x and Pt-WO x catalysts in the sorbitol hydrogenolysis because both catalyst candidates have weak ability to cleave C–C bond. Similar to the xylitol hydrogenolysis, a biphasic solvent system was necessary to extract hexanols (HxOHs) from water to an organic phase to suppress overhydrogenolysis over Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Table 12 ). The yields of 3-/2-HxOHs reached 36% and 8%, respectively, while 1-HxOH was almost not detected [ 49 ]. In contrast, overhydrogenolysis was significantly prohibited over Pt-WO x /SiO2 even only using a water solvent, and the 12% yield of 1-HxOH was obtained with slightly higher yields of 3-/2-HxOHs [ 61 ]. For the Ru-based catalysts, it was difficult to obtain HxOHs with high yield due to the C–C and C–O hydrogenolysis, and EG, 1,2-PrD, and glycerol are the common products [ 124 ]. Attempts have also been made for transformation of cellulose using bimetallic catalysts. The similar system of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 + H2O/organic solvent with H2SO4, which has roles in promoting the cellulose hydrolysis into water-soluble oligosaccharides and stabilizing interfacial ReOH sites, provided a total yield of HxOHs up to ~60% (40% 3-HxOH) at relatively low temperature [ 125 ]. Other attempts focus on the transformation of cellulose into EG and ethanol over WO x -promoted catalysts at higher reaction temperature. Considering the necessity of acidic sites for the depolymerization of cellulose, large amount of WO x is required. The reaction pathway includes the C–C hydrogenolysis via the retro-aldol condensation mechanism, C–O hydrogenolysis, dehydration, and hydrogenation (Fig. 20 ). Liao et al. [ 126 ] used biochar that was prepared by a pyrolysis method to support Ru-WO x pairs, and a high carbon-based yield of EG (69% based on carbon) was obtained. The further hydrogenolysis of EG affords ethanol, which can be used as biofuel, and Ru-WO x /HZSM-5 gave a 77% carbon-based yield of ethanol [ 127 ]. The addition of Ru/WO x (5 wt% Ru) increased the carbon-based yield to 88%, which was due to the enhanced retro-aldol condensation reaction. Zhang et al. [ 128 ] dispersed Pt particles over mesoporous WO x , and the catalyst gave 30% carbon-based yield of ethanol. The introduction of small amount of MoO x (0.1 wt%) increased the ethanol yield (43%, carbon-based) because MoO x -Pt-WO x interfacial sites promoted the C–O hydrogenolysis of EG to ethanol. In addition to the aforementioned route of the partial HDO for polyols, some other approaches are also effective. In the hydroconversion of biomass-derived polyols (for example, erythritol (C4 platform sugar alcohol)), Cu catalysts, which are typical catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PrD [ 31 ], have been reported to produce diols as major products, but their yields were quite low [ 131 ]. We developed the deoxydehydration (DODH) + hydrogenation systems [ 4,132,133 ] that enable HDO of erythritol to 1,2-BuD (79% yield), xylitol to C5 mono-alcohols (98%), and sorbitol to C6 diols (85%) over ReO x -Pd/CeO2 [ 134 ]. On the other hand, more complicated reaction processes involved DODH have been realized to selectively produce 1,4-BuD from 1,4-anhydroerythritol over ReO x -Au/CeO2 + ReO x /C (90% yield) [ 135 ], CeO2 + ReO x /C (89%) [ 136 ] and ReO x -Au/CeO2 + ReO x /WO3-ZrO2 (55%) [ 137 ]. Less expensive Mo-based DODH catalysts than Re-based ones have been developed recently [ 138 ]. Although the catalyst life should be further improved, such DODH-based systems seem promising for the selective synthesis of oxygenates from sugar alcohols with four or more carbon atoms. For the one-pot conversion of cellulose, Zhang [ 139 ] found that tungsten-based catalysts combined with Ru and Ni catalysts successfully catalyzed cellulose transformation into EG, which involved the hydrolysis, C–C bond hydrogenolysis, and hydrogenation. 3.2 Total HDO of biomass derivatives and oxygen-containing aromatic plastics 3.2.1 C5 and C6 linear alkanes from sugars Total HDO of oxygenates offers a variety of alkanes, and some of them can be used as transportation fuels. Carbohydrates such as sugars, xylan and cellulose have C5 and C6 carbon frameworks, and the total HDO gives n-pentane and n-hexane, which are in the gasoline range. The C–C dissociation should be suppressed during the total HDO because the carbon chain length is already near the lower limit of gasoline range. The stepwise hydrogenolysis of carbohydrates or the hydrogenation products (sugar alcohols) under severe conditions gives high yield of alkanes with minor C–C dissociation products (Table 13 ) over Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalysts, and this yield is higher than those obtained from other catalytic systems. For example, zeolite-supported monometallic Ni catalysts suffered from the low yield of n-alkanes in HDO of both sorbitol [ 140–142 ] and xylitol due to isomerization reactions [ 143 ], and the C–C cleavage reactions proceeded over Pt-based catalysts also decreased the selectivity to n-alkanes [ 144–146 ]. Akin to the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst, Ir-WO x /SiO2 catalyzed the HDO of cellulose to C6 alkanes via the formation of sorbitol intermediate, but higher reaction temperature was required and the final C6 products were a mixture of n-hexane, methyl cyclopentane, cyclohexane, and so on [ 147 ]. Typical solvents for total HDO of sugar derivatives are biphasic mixture of water and alkane. Water is a better solvent than alkanes for the C–O hydrogenolysis over Ir-M'O x catalysts and has higher solubility of oxygenated intermediates. Alkane solvent was added for extraction and collection of the produced pentane and hexane. 3.2.2 Cycloalkanes from lignin and aromatic plastics Cycloalkanes have higher octane number than n-pentane and n-hexane and are more suitable as gasoline. In addition, cycloalkanes can be used as stable hydrogen carriers. Among major biomass resources, only lignin has cyclic carbon units in the structure, and total HDO of lignin over bimetallic catalysts would provide cycloalkanes [ 148 ]. Considering the ether bonds between aromatic units in lignin, Li emphasized several chemicals with β-O-4, α-O-4, and 4-O-5 linkages as model compounds (Table 14 , entries 1–5) and investigated the HDO performance of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalysts [ 149 ]. Hydrocarbon solvent (cycloalkane) was used because of the low solubility of substrate and intermediates in a water solvent. It was found that all the screened ethers were converted into cycloalkanes via hydrogenation + C–O hydrogenolysis reactions. The main product was cyclohexane, and its yield was almost independent on OH and OCH3 groups in the β-O-4 model compounds. It should be noted that the 4-O-5 model compound diphenyl ether, which has relatively stable aryl–aryl ether bonds, can be almost fully converted into cyclohexane with 98% carbon-based yield. The catalyst had lower Ir loading and higher Re/Ir ratio than those mentioned in the previous section for hydrogenolysis of polyols. The lower Re/Ir ratio such as 0.2 wt% Ir, 0.5 wt% Re in this reaction (HDO of phenethoxybenzene; entry 6 of Table 14) gave lower conversion (23%) of substrate. The acidity induced by a large amount of Re was proposed to be responsible for the dissociation of the linkage on the basis of the result that 2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1- phenylethanol (substrate of entry 3 in Table 14) was converted to monomers over ReO x /SiO2 under Ar atmosphere. The co-presence of monometallic ReO x and bimetallic Ir-ReO x species can be beneficial to the HDO of lignin. They further tested the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst after increasing the metal amounts (1 wt% Ir, 5 wt% Re) for the direct transformation of real lignins and woody biomass to naphthalenes. The selected organosolv poplar lignin, enzymolysis lignin, and commercial alkaline lignin provided the carbon yield of C7–C9 cyclohexanes at 29%, 15%, and 9%, respectively. Nevertheless, the Ir-ReO x catalysts are superior catalyst candidates in the dissociation of C–O bond to other ones. In addition, bimetallic Ru-ReO x catalysts supported on carbon materials are also highly active in the conversion of lignin derivatives [ 150 ]. Jae et al. [ 151 ] investigated the effect of carbon support and found that CNT- and carbon black-supported Ru-ReO x pairs showed higher activity than activated carbon (AC)-supported catalyst in lignin-derived guaiacol conversion. They ascribed the lower activity to the weaker interaction between Ru and ReO x species on AC, and the main product was switched from cyclohexanol with 50%–60% yield at 473 K to cyclohexane with ~90% ring-based yield of cyclohexane at 513 K, which is even higher than the HDO of guaiacol catalyzed by Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (0.2 wt% Ir, 2 wt% Re; 79% ring-based yield) [ 149 ]. As an extension of guaiacol, isoeugenol can be selectively converted into propylcyclohexane over Ir-ReO x /Al2O3 (2.9 wt% Ir, 4.6 wt% Re) with 99% ring-based yield at 523 K and 4 MPa using dodecane as a solvent (Eq. (2)) [ 152 ]. In general, the direct conversion of lignin into fine chemicals is rather difficult, but progresses on the HDO of its model compounds have been achieved over other bimetallic catalysts. For example, guaiacol has been efficiently converted into cyclohexane over Cu-Ni and Ni-Mo catalysts including hydrogenolysis, hydrogenation, and dehydration [ 153 ]. (2) Akin to lignin derivatives, some plastic wastes also contain aromatic ring, and enormous efforts have been devoted to green management of plastic wastes into plastic monomers, fuels and chemicals [ 10 ], for example, polycarbonate (PC). Wang et al. [ 154 ] conducted the pioneering work using Ru/Nb2O5 catalyst for upgrading of various aromatic plastic wastes to arenes (75%–85% yield, based on the number of aromatic ring mole) via the hydrogenolysis of C–O and/or C–C linkages. Here, Nb2O5 worked as a solid acid as well as a support. Recently, Liu et al. [ 15 ] performed the HDO of a series of the aforementioned plastic wastes including PC, polyethylene terephthalate (PET), polybutylene terephthalate (PBT), polyphenylene oxide (PPO), and their mixtures to cycloalkanes over the HZSM-5-promoted Ru-ReO x /SiO2 catalytic system. They initially screened typical SiO2-supported bimetallic catalysts in the HDO of PC (Fig. 21 ) and found that Ru-ReO x /SiO2 and Rh-ReO x /SiO2 were effective to obtain C15 cycloalkane, whereas Ir-ReO x /SiO2 was inactive for this reaction (Table 15 ). The C15 cycloalkane can be a component of jet fuel. The optimized ratio of Re to Ru was 0.5, and the maximum yield of C15 cycloalkane reached 93% (based on the mole of bisphenol A) at 453 K and 3 MPa H2. Both monometallic Ru/SiO2 and ReO x /SiO2 as well as their physical mixture showed no conversion, suggesting that Ru-ReO x interface worked as the active site. The time course for the PC HDO showed that saturated C15 mono-oxygenates (S-C15 oxygenates(1O)) were gradually formed and then decreased with the time extension, while the amount of target product of C15 cycloalkane continuously increased (Fig. 22(A) ). Accordingly, the S-C15 oxygenates(1O) were intermediates during the reaction. To further elucidate the reaction pathway, the HDO of diphenyl carbonate as a model compound was carried out. In the initial stage, main products were cyclohexane and cyclohexanol, and their yields gradually increased with reducing the amounts of unsaturated products (benzene, phenol and cyclohexanone, Fig. 22(B)). Cyclohexanol was mainly formed by phenol hydrogenation by an intermediate of cyclohexanone (Fig. 22(C)), whereas HDO of cyclohexanol to cyclohexane was very slow (Fig. 22(D)). Accordingly, cyclohexane is mainly formed by the hydrogenation of benzene during the conversion of diphenyl carbonate. Ring- hydrogenation products of diphenyl carbonate were not detected at all during the reaction, suggesting that direct hydrogenolysis of C–O bond between the benzene ring and ester group occurred prior to the hydrogenation and hydrolysis reactions. Therefore, the hydrogenolysis of C–O bond between the benzene ring and ester group in PC was the first step, and the subsequent hydrogenation of C15 aromatics and HDO of C15 monophenols proceeded at the later step (Fig. 22(E)). It should be noted that the hydrogenation of C15 aromatics is much faster than the HDO of C15 phenols, and the ring hydrogenation afforded C15 cyclic alcohol. The sequent HDO of C15 cyclic alcohol to C15 bicycloalkane was the r.d.s in the whole reaction network. The kinetic study using cyclohexanol as a model substrate suggested the direct C–O hydrogenolysis mechanism (first reaction order with respect to H2) over Ru-ReO x /SiO2 (Re/Ru = 0.5). Meanwhile, the combination of solid acidic zeolites such as HZSM-5 altered the reaction pathway to the dehydration + hydrogenation of cyclohexanol, and the reaction rate was drastically improved. Inspired from the work above, they applied the HZSM-5-promoted Ru-ReO x /SiO2 catalytic system to various oxygen-containing aromatic plastic wastes including PC, PET, PBT, PPO, and the mixture of the aforementioned plastics were selectively transformed into cycloalkanes (Fig. 23 ). In the HDO of waste PET, the addition of water into an organic solvent would promote the depolymerization, and the sources of PET also affected the catalyst performance. The yield of cycloalkanes was lower using red fibric as a substrate, which might be due to the additive that is contained in the plastic and causes catalyst deactivation [ 15 ]. In the HDO of PPO, the yield was much lower because of the high stability of ether C–O bonds linking the aromatic rings. For such plastic, the Ir-ReO x catalyst might be useful as we discussed in this part because it can catalyze the conversion of diphenyl ether into cyclohexane. This system was also applicable to the mixture of plastics HDO, and the theoretical hydrogen storage capacity reached 5.3 wt%–5.7 wt%, which was roughly close to the value using 2 wt% Pt/γ-Al2O3 as a dehydrogenation catalyst. The result indicates that H2 is widely accessible from the products of HDO of aromatic plastic wastes, and the combination of HZSM-5 and Ru-ReO x /SiO2 as an HDO system was promising for the plastic circular economy and hydrogen storage and transportation. For upgrading plastic wastes, progress has also been made over bimetallic catalysts other than HDO. Polyolefins (no heteroatom) can be transformed into fuels by hydrocracking over Pt-WO x [ 155–157 ] and zeolites-supported metal bifunctional catalysts [ 16 ] or by hydrogenolysis over WO x -, MoO x -, and VO x -modified Ru/ZrO2 catalysts [ 158,159 ]; heteroatom-containing plastics, for example, polyesters and PCs are able to produce diols, acid compounds, and phenols with proper polymers as starting materials over Ru-based homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts via C–O or C–C bond hydrogenolysis [ 16 ]. 3.2.3 Long-chain alkanes from C–C coupling products of biomass-derived compounds In order to accommodate the demand for the usage in gasoline (C5–C12), jet fuel (C8–C16), diesel fuel (C9–C22), and lubricant base oils (C20–C50), it is imperative to extend the carbon chain of alkanes. Branches in the carbon chain are essential for gasoline (to increase the octane number), jet fuel and lubricant (to lower the freezing point). The formation of such carbon chains can be achieved through C–C coupling of biomass-derived compounds with carbonyl group and furan platforms, such as furfural, 2-alkylfuran, aldehydes and enals, followed by subsequent hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [ 40,160–162 ]. These processes enable the production of a diverse range of high value-added alkanes with branched structures. Total HDO of polyfunctionalized biomass derivatives has been well discussed [ 163–165 ] and reviewed [ 166 ], we focus on the catalytic systems based on the bimetallic catalysts. Mascal et al. [ 167 ] reported a route of gasoline-range branched C7–C10 hydrocarbons production using biomass-derived levulinic acid as a starting material. The reaction network involves intramolecular dehydration, base-catalyzed the dimerization, and the final step catalyzed by Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (4 wt% Ir, Re/Ir = 1) at 493 K and 5.5 MPa H2. The former two steps were relatively easy to be achieved with high yield, and the HDO of lactones gave 70% carbon-based yield of branched C10 alkane (Fig. 24 ). Moreover, the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst exhibited good stability in the lactone HDO reactions. Vlachos et al. [ 40,160–162 ] found that both Ir-ReO x /SiO2 and Ir-MoO x /SiO2 catalysts showed remarkable efficacy in the complete HDO of large furan compounds containing 2–3 furan rings, yielding branched alkanes with carbon numbers ranging from 12 to 34 (Fig. 25 ). The Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst with the Re/Ir ratio of 2 exhibited the good performance, while the Ir-MoO x /SiO2 catalyst with the Mo/Ir ratio of 0.13 displayed even higher HDO activity than the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst with the Re/Ir ratio of 0.13. Although Ir-MoO x /SiO2 catalyst is not effective in the selective hydrogenolysis (partial HDO) of glycerol to 1,3-PrD [ 32 ], this catalyst is effective in the total HDO. The carbon-based yields of the corresponding alkanes with the same number of carbon atoms as the substrates ranged from 43% to 99%, depending on the structural characteristics of furan compounds. The stability of both catalysts was found to be excellent. The reaction pathway for the HDO of large furan compounds was elucidated based on the time-dependent experiments and control experiments using the key intermediates (Fig. 26 ). It was found that the furan moieties of large furan compounds undergo simultaneous ring saturation and ring opening to form a complex mixture of oxygenates consisting of tetrahydrofuran rings, mono-keto groups, and mono-hydroxy group. These oxygenates then underwent the cascade reactions consisting of hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation reactions to form alkanes. The carbon atom adjacent to the furan and saturated furan ring in substrates or intermediate compounds underwent C–C bond scission, resulting in a small fraction of lighter linear alkanes. The rate of C–C bond cracking in the intermediates containing tetrahydrofuran rings was significantly slower compared to the molecules with furan rings. The selectivity of branched alkanes derived from different structural substrates can be attributed to the relative stability of carbocations formed from large furan molecules.
