The stability of these carbocations follows the order: primary < secondary < tertiary < furfuryl carbons. Consequently, the C–C fragmentation at the quaternary carbon adjacent to the furan moiety occurred preferentially. As a result, the selectivity of target C13 branched alkanes from the HDO of 5,5'-(propane-2,2-diyl)bis(2-methylfuran) was the lowest. Mechanistically, the high activity of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 and Ir-MoO x /SiO2 originates from the synergistic effect between metallic Ir sites and oxophilic partially reduced ReO x (or MoO x ) species, the former of which is responsible for the hydrogenation and the latter of which promotes the ring opening, cleavage of etheric and alcoholic C–O bonds, as well as hydrogenation of C=O bonds. The Ir-MoO x /SiO2 catalyst exhibits higher yields of C–C cracking products compared to the Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of 5,5'-(furan-2-ylmethylene)bis(2-methylfuran), owing to its lower ring saturation activity. 3.3 HDO of carbonyl compounds 3.3.1 Carboxylic acid and esters The long-chain fatty acid esters of glycerol (triglycerides), which are widely contained in bio-based oils (an annual production exceeding 2 × 102 million tons) [ 168 ], can be a renewable source of fuels and chemicals. In China, about 5 million tons of waste cooking oils are generated every year [ 169 ], and they can be converted into fatty acid methyl esters by transesterification with methanol. Fatty acid methyl esters are mainly used as biodiesel and can be also used as renewable feedstocks of other compounds, because of the easier handling of fatty acid methyl esters than that of triglycerides. In addition, many carboxylic acids are included as platform chemicals in the biomass refinery. Many works focus on the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids or esters to alcohols as sources of chemicals [ 170,171 ]. Cu-based catalysts such as copper chromite are classical ones for the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids or esters to alcohols [ 172,173 ], and various bimetallic catalysts have been also reported [ 172 ], for example, Ru-MoO x [ 100 ], Ir-MoO x [ 174 ] and Cu-based bimetallic candidates [ 175 ]. Fuchikami et al. [ 176 ] reported in 1990s that the synergistic effect between Re2(CO)10, Mo(CO)6, or W(CO)6 and supported platinum-group metals promoted the hydroconversion of various carboxylic acids and dicarboxylic acid monomethyl esters into the corresponding mono-alcohols and diols. In fact, reduced Re species itself is active in this reaction. We found that the addition of small amount of Pd as a modifier to Re/SiO2 promoted the reduction of Re species and the high yield of alcohols can be achieved over this Re-Pd/SiO2, for example, 94% yield of 1-octadecanol and 89% yield of 1,4-BuD in the HDO of stearic acid [ 177,178 ] and succinic acid [ 71 ], respectively. Total HDO of fatty acids (Eq. (3)) or esters (Eq. (4)), both of which are widely accessible from vegetable oils into long-chain alkanes, is an attractive strategy to produce biofuel with higher quality than fatty acid methyl esters. Various effective catalysts have been reported such as supported monometallic Pt [ 179 ], Fe [ 180,181 ], Co [ 182 ], Ru [ 183,184 ], metal phosphides [ 185,186 ], metal carbides [ 187,188 ] catalysts and bimetallic Ni-Mo catalysts [ 189–192 ] for the production of diesel-range alkanes by the HDO of fatty acids and esters, and some candidates can be directly used for the HDO of vegetable oils [ 193–195 ]. However, the decarboxylation, decarbonylation, and cracking would lead to some loss of carbon atoms. The loss of carbon atom is sometimes useful such as the case of the production of jet fuel, and bimetallic NiMo and NiW catalysts are common candidates for vegetable oils hydrocracking into lighter alkanes [ 196 ]. Monometallic Ru catalysts are typical ones for the HDO of carboxylic acids or esters with minimum loss of carbon, and the support much affects the selectivity patterns. A Ru/HZSM-5 (1.6 wt% Ru) gave 51% mole-based selectivity of C9-C16 cracking alkanes products at the 40% conversion of stearic acid (C17H35COOH), whereas a basic La(OH)3-supported Ru catalyst showed 96% mole-based selectivity to n-C17 alkane at the full conversion under the identical reaction conditions of 473 K and 4 MPa H2 [ 183 ]. When methyl stearate (C17H35COOCH3) was used as a substrate, the main product became n-C17 alkane with ~60% carbon-based yield under 473 K and 3 MPa H2 over Ru/HZSM-5 (1.0 wt% Ru) [ 184 ]. In both cases, the yield of n-C18 alkane is very low due to side reactions. On the other hand, HDO reactions over non-noble metal catalytic systems generally were performed at high reaction temperatures (>533 K) [ 197 ], and the decarboxylation and/or decarbonylation could be inevitable. For example, the HDO of oleic acid (C17H33COOH) gave 83% mole-based yield of n-C18 alkane together with ~15% mole-based yield of n-C17 alkane over Fe catalyst at 563 K and 3 MPa H2 [ 181 ]. With this regard, the application of bimetallic catalysts owing to the synergy in metal-metal oxide interface can relieve the burden of carbon loss in the HDO of fatty acids and esters. (3) R1COOH + 3H2 → R1CH3 + 2H2O (4) R1COOR2 + 4H2 → R1CH3 + 2H2O + R2H Saha et al. [ 70 ] investigated the HDO of stearic acid over various bimetallic catalysts (Table 16 ), and Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (4 wt% Ir, Re/Ir = 3) showed 94% carbon-based yield of n-C18 alkane at 453 K and 2 MPa H2. In contrast, a large amount of stearyl alcohol remained unconverted over other bimetallic catalysts. n-C17 alkane was the main by-product over Ru-ReO x /SiO2 and Rh-ReO x /SiO2 catalysts, probably via the decarbonylation and/or decarboxylation of stearic acid. It should be pointed out that monometallic ReO x /SiO2 (12 wt%) gave the main product of stearyl alcohol via the stearic acid hydrogenation with low conversion, which is consistent with our previous findings [ 178 ]. Considering that Ir/SiO2 was inactive for this reaction, the strong synergy between Ir and ReO x significantly promoted the targeted reaction of stearic acid into n-C18 alkane. The required amount of Re was large for the HDO of stearic acid than polyols, and they ascribed it to the fact that the activation of stearic acid is more difficult compared to polyols, and excess amount of partially reduced ReO x sites affords abundant Lewis acid sites to promote the adsorption of stearic acid. To further clarify the reaction route, time courses for the HDO of both stearic acid and methyl stearate were investigated (Fig. 27 ). 1-Octadecanol and n-C18 alkane were initially co-produced, and n-C18 alkane was increased with decreasing the selectivity to 1-octadecanol (Fig. 27(A)). In the case of the stearic acid HDO, the selectivity change became faster when the conversion of stearic acid reached almost 100%. This means that the intrinsic activity in the 1-octadecanol hydrogenolysis is high but suppressed by the presence of stearic acid probably by the competitive adsorption of substrates. In the case of methyl stearate, the HDO reaction was slower than that of stearic acid, and n-C18 alkane selectivity maintained ~90% (based on carbon) during the process with low selectivity to 1-octadecanol (Fig. 27(B)). No stearic acid was detected, suggesting that acyl C–O bond was prone to be cleaved to form octadecanal, which was then quickly hydrogenated to 1-octadecanol. The HDO of 1-octadecanal (Fig. 28 , route (i)) could be fast because stearic acid is not present in the reaction system. Moreover, they figured out that the formation of C17 alkane originated from the decarbonylation rather than the decarboxylation by controlling experiments under N2 atmosphere. Next, they tested the HDO of vegetable oils such as palm oil, soybean oil, and sunflower oil, and these oils were readily converted into diesel-range alkanes with 79%–85% carbon-based yields at 453 K and 2 MPa H2. However, the yield of diesel-range alkanes was low from waste cooking oil due to the alkali metal cations deactivating the active sites of Ir-ReO x /SiO2. TiO2 (mixture of anatase and rutile)-supported Ru-MoOx and Ru-ReO x catalysts were also effective to produce n-alkanes by HDO reactions. In both cases, the decarbonylation proceeded over Ru/TiO2. The loading of ReO x species onto Ru/TiO2 increased the yield of n-C18 alkane in HDO of ethyl stearate (C17H35COOCH2CH3), where the ratio of n-C18/n-C17 alkanes gradually increased and saturated at about 3 (70% mole-based selectivity to n-C18 and 22% mole-based selectivity to n-C17 alkane at the full conversion of ethyl stearate) with the increase in the Re amount ranging from 0.5 wt% to 10 wt% at 493 K and 3 MPa H2 [ 197 ]. The reaction pathway was altered because of the strong interaction between Ru and ReO x . The authors correlated the n-C18/n-C17 ratio with the total acid amount acquired by NH3-TPD from Ru/TiO2 and Ru-ReO x /TiO2 with the varied Re amount, and a linear relationship was observed. In particular, the weak acid sites on the Ru-ReO x /TiO2 were suggested to play a vital role in the HDO of ethyl stearate. Moreover, the reaction pathway was similar to Ir-ReO x /SiO2, but the dehydration + hydrogenation (Fig. 28, route (ii)) in the final step was proposed. This bimetallic catalyst was stable with its repeated usage. Similarly, Ru-MoO x /TiO2 (5.3 wt% Ru, Mo/Ru = 0.5) catalyzed the HDO of lauric acid (C11H23COOH) to dodecane with the 80% mole-based yield at 503 K and 4 MPa H2 [ 198 ]. At lower reaction temperatures, dodecyl dodecanoate was detected due to the esterification of lauric acid and 1-dodecanol, and 1-dodecanol became the main product (Fig. 29(A) ). At higher reaction temperatures, 1-dodecanol was further converted into dodecane by the dehydration + hydrogenation. In addition, higher H2 pressure favored 1-dodecanol by suppressing the formation of esterification product (Fig. 29(B)), but the further increase of H2 pressure would promote the conversion of 1-dodecanol into dodecane. This system could be applied to the HDO of various fatty acids and carboxylic acid, such as stearic acid and succinic acid. Although the target products in this study were alcohols, the production of corresponding alkanes can be expected. Unfortunately, the Ru-MoO x /TiO2 is not a robust candidate due to the aggregation of Ru nanoparticles. In addition, MoO x -modified Pt/TiO2 was also found to be effective for the HDO of lauric acid to dodecane with the 86% mole-based yield [ 199 ]. The HDO of fatty acid is also feasible over Pt-WO x catalyst. Janampelli et al. [ 200 ] employed Pt-WO x /Al2O3 for the HDO of oleic acid (C17H33COOH) and its methyl esters that contain C=C bond. Since the activation of H2 is relatively easy on a Pt surface, and the hydrogenation of double bond would expect to proceed fast. Regardless of metal amount on the Pt/Al2O3, the dominant product was C17 alkane by the decarbonylation and/or decarboxylation. In contrast, Pt-WO x /Al2O3 (4 wt% Pt, 8 wt% W) showed 67% and 32% (based on mass) selectivity to C18, and C17 alkanes at the full conversion (593 K, 2.5 MPa), respectively. The reaction route over Pt-WO x /Al2O3 was essentially the same as that over the Ru-ReO x /TiO2 catalyst. A gradually enhanced activity was found in the reuse experiment with no aggregation of Pt particles as verified by XRD, which might be due to the reconstruction of Pt-WO x interface during the test. 3.3.2 Amides Amines have wide applications in polymer industry [ 201 ] and fine chemicals [ 202 ] and are anticipated to be obtained by HDO of amides (Eq. (5)). Polyamides (PAs) are one of major class of plastics, and the consumption of PAs exceeded 7 million tons in 2022 [ 203 ]. The depolymerization by catalytic hydrogenation is one promising process for green management of waste PA. Furthermore, depolymerization of polypeptide can be also a useful reaction for the synthesis of N-containing chemicals from biomass. However, it is known that the reactivity of amides is even lower than that of carboxylic acids [ 204 ], which remains a great challenge to activate the C=O bond in amides. (5) R1CONR2R3 + 2H2 → R1CH2NR2R3 + H2O The pioneering work of amide HDO was reported by Fuchikami et al. [ 205 ], where they found that the reaction was much promoted by the addition of transition metal complexes, including Re2(CO)10, W(CO)6, or Mo(CO)6, onto homogeneous (Rh6(CO)16 or Ru3(CO)12) and heterogeneous catalysts (Rh/C or Ru/Al2O3). Later, Whyman et al. [ 206 ] employed Rh6(CO)16 and Mo(CO)6 to prepare in-situ formed bimetallic particles (Mo/Rh = 0.55) that gave high selectivity of the liquid-phase hydrogenation of CyCONH2 (Cy: cyclohexyl) to CyCH2NH2. They also made attempts to prepare silica-supported bimetallic nanoparticles, but the supported catalyst showed poor activity and would be deactivated with its repeated usage. A series of in-situ formed Ru/Re and Rh/Re catalysts were successfully developed by the same group, and the selectivity to CyCH2NH2 was further improved to 95% at 90% conversion [ 207 ]. Recent studies have developed robust supported bimetallic catalysts for the reduction of primary amides [ 208 ], and Ru nanoparticles modified by WO x and MoO x species are promising candidates as listed in Table 17 . Amides were selectively converted into corresponding primary amines under the optimized conditions, and the by-products mainly included primary alcohols, and secondary amines such as (C6H11)2NH and (CyCH2)2NH in HDO of hexanamide and CyCONH2, respectively. We found that the addition of CeO2 drastically promoted the CyCONH2 reduction over the Rh-MoO x /SiO2 in terms of both activity and selectivity, which was explained by the surface modification with weakly-basic site on CeO2 [ 209 ]. Similar promotion effect was also observed as the better performance of dispersed Ru-WO x catalyst on basic MgAl2O4 spinel than SiO2 support [ 210 ]. In addition to the HDO of primary amides, the conversion of secondary amides is also important because it can provide with valuable reference for the depolymerization of PAs. De Vos et al. [ 211 ] found that N-hexylhexanamide, a model compound of secondary amide, can be converted into hexylamine with ~70% carbon-based yield by the ammonolytic hydrogenation over a complex of Nb2O5 and Ru-WO x /MgAl2O4 (4 wt% Ru, W/Ru = 8) catalysts at 473 K, 5 MPa H2 and 0.6 MPa NH3. Nb2O5 served as Lewis acid that catalyzes the ammonolysis by a nucleophilic attack of NH3 to form hexylamine together with hexanamide. Subsequently, Ru-WO x /MgAl2O4 promoted the HDO of hexanamide and hydrogenation of hexanenitrile into hexylamine. By this catalytic system, industrial PAs, including PA-1010, PA-11, and PA-12, were depolymerized into α,ω-diamine monomer with carbon-based yields between 21% and 43%. However, sulfur-containing compounds even with a very small amount would deactivate the Ru-WO x /MgAl2O4 catalyst, and the pretreatment to remove such compounds is necessary. Furthermore, the HDO of tertiary amides proceed over MoO x -modified Pt [ 212 ] and Ir [ 213 ] catalysts, and ~80% yield of N-ethylmorpholine was obtained via the HDO of N-acetylmorpholine. For the reductive depolymerization of PAs, both homogenous Ru complex and heterogenous catalysts (Ru/CeO2 and Pt/CeO2) have shown interesting results. Schaub et al. used a homogenous Ru catalyst for PAs conversion with different molecular weights, and 70% yield (based on the repeating unit of PA-66 mole) of 1,6-hexanediamine together with 47% yield (based on the repeating unit of PA-66 mole) of 1,6-hexanediol was achieved using PA-66 (M n=5250 g/mol) at 473 K and 8 MPa H2 [ 215 ]. However, this system was very sensitive to the acidity of PAs, and no desired products were detected when PAs with similar or lower molecular weights possessed an excess of acidic end groups. This might be related to the poisoning of active Ru complex caused by acidic groups in PAs. On the other hand, the main products were alkanes over CeO2-supported Ru and Pt (0.5 wt% for each metal) catalysts [ 216 ]. The selectivity patterns in the conversion of PAs including PA-6, PA-66, PA-12, and PA-612 were different over the two catalysts, where methane was mainly formed for Ru/CeO2 while n-hexane and/or n-dodecane were the main products for Pt/CeO2. For example, depolymerization of PA-6 (M n = 27380 g/mol) gave 96% carbon-based yield of methane over Ru/CeO2, whereas a maximum n-hexane yield of 64% with 15% yield (both in carbon-based value) of n-pentane was obtained over Pt/CeO2 at 598 K and 5 MPa H2 with an appropriate reaction time. Although the CeO2-supported catalysts were reusable, but both selectivity and catalytic efficiency remained to improve. We believe that the aforementioned bimetallic catalysts, noble metal modified by metal oxide discussed in this review could be the promising candidates in the hydroconversion of PAs into value-added chemicals owing to the different active sites present for hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of C–O/C–N bond. 4 Conclusions and outlook This review has focused on the development of bimetallic catalysts and their wide application in the production of fine chemicals and fuels in terms of biomass refinery and plastics/polymers conversion by hydrodeoxygenation. The partially reduced metal oxides (ReO x , WO x , MoO x , FeO x ) strongly intreacted with noble metal surface (Ir, Pt, Ru), and such interaction could be further enhanced by tuning the composition, using support with small surface area, and so on. Realizing the significance of affinity between metal and metal oxide, rational design of catalyst structure is highly desired for the improvement of catalytic performance. The metal-oxide-modified noble metal catalysts have versatility: the catalyst optimized for the glycerol hydrogenolysis, which is a very important biomass valorization reaction and a model reaction at the same time, can be applied to other substrates and reactions such as the partial HDO of more complicated sugar alcohols, total HDO of various oxygenates, and depolymerization of waste plastics. Reaction mechanisms of selective C–O bond cleavage have been summarized, including direct hydrogenolysis with hydride attack and indirect acid-involved mechanism. The former mechanism is on the basis of the first reaction order with respect to H2 pressure, and the latter mechanism can be supported the fact from incorporation of isotopes. At present, the reaction mechanism is still open for discussion, and it lacks direct evidence for both mechanisms. Water is often used as a solvent in the hydrogenolysis of polyols to increase the solubility, but it makes more difficult to reveal the potential mechanism due to the fast isotope exchange between active hydrogen species and water solvent. We believe that the development of new measurement technology in the future affords the chance to trap and detect those intermediates. The catalytic performances in HDO reactions leave the space to be improved. In the HDO of polyols and sugar alcohols, desired diols and mono-alcohols are prone to undergo overreaction, lowering the selectivity to desired products. It is important to make products desorb quickly from the catalyst surface, and separate from the catalytic system timely. Controlling wettability of catalyst surface might be an effective approach to promoting the HDO reactions since water and oxygenates are co-produced and they are hydrophilic. Hydrophobization of catalyst support by organosilanes modification might facilitate the separation of products from the catalysts, and a higher selectivity of desired product can be thus obtained. The use of other supports with small BET surface area is reasonable to construct interface of metal and metal oxide. In some cases, deep reduction of metal oxide (modifier) into low valence, which is difficult to realize on the conventional supports, would enhance catalytic activity or alter selectivity patterns. For the development of more precisely tuned catalysts, we surmise that zeolites might be potential supports to construct the interface. The acidic sites in zeolites are controllable [ 217 ], which is important for substrates activation over the bifunctional catalysts. In addition, the defect sites in zeolites can dynamically trap metal species under certain conditions [ 218,219 ], particularly for ReO x and WO x species that have high mobility. Other methods for catalyst preparation may also help to enhance the interaction. The use of atomic layer deposition can realize the modification of supported metal nanopartciles: The secondary metal can be anchored onto metal surface by depositing the two metals sequentially at a low reaction temperature where the deposition on oxide support is slower than the deposition on previously deposited metal nanoparticles [ 220 ]. Moreover, distinguishable reducibility of metal clusters allows the manipulation of metal coverage in the preparation of core-shell materials, and it inspires new methods to maximize the coverage of metal oxide on metal surface. On the other hand, catalyst stability is another key point in the potential practical applications. Many bimetallic catalysts are reusable under their own ideal conditions, and most of them discussed in this review are under batch reactors. However, the stability of the catalysts might be different under industrial conditions or using fixed-bed reactors. Metal sintering, leaching, coke formation, and deconstruction of metal-metal oxide interface would drastically decrease the activity, and regeneration methods as well as highly stable catalysts are desired. Huber, ACS Catal., 2015, 5, 1804–1825. Yoshinao Nakagawa (Tohoku University) received his Ph.D. in 2005 from the Graduate School of Engineering, the University of Tokyo. After 4 years of postdoctoral research in the University of Tokyo, he joined the research group of Keiichi Tomishige at University of Tsukuba. He moved to Tohoku University and became an assistant professor in 2010. Since 2013, he has been an associate professor. His current research interests are selective catalytic oxidations and reductions, especially those of biomass-related compounds. Keiichi Tomishige received his B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. from the Graduate School of Science, Department of Chemistry, the University of Tokyo. During his Ph.D. course in 1994, he moved to the Graduate School of Engineering, The University of Tokyo as a research associate. In 1998, he became a lecturer, and then he moved to Institute of Materials Science, University of Tsukuba as a lecturer in 2001. Since 2004 he has been an associate professor, Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba. Since 2010, he has been a professor, School of Engineering, Tohoku University. His research interests are the development of heterogeneous catalysts for production of biomass-derived chemicals and non-reductive CO2 conversion. He has also a role of Associate Editor of Green Chemistry.

coredata.dc:description: Valorization of biomass and plastics is an urgent assignment to achieve the goal of carbon neutrality. Hydrodeoxygenation using bimetallic catalysts with distinct active sites is one of the most effective approaches to producing fuels and chemicals via C–O/C–C bonds hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation. Rational design of bimetallic catalysts has been progressed in recent studies owing to the understanding of synergy and strong mutual interaction between metal nanoparticles and metal oxide species. Thus, activity of bimetallic catalysts has been further improved, and the chemoselectivity for suppression of C–C bond dissociation and the regioselectivity among different C–O bonds, which have less been achieved before, are realized in the hydrodeoxygenation reactions. The catalytic performances, catalyst structures, and reaction mechanisms are directly compared and discussed in details based on the C–O bond cleavage using glycerol and 1,2-propanediol hydrogenolysis as model reactions over Ir-, Pt-, and Ru-based bimetallic catalysts. Finally, application of these bimetallic catalysts to conversion of lignocellulose-derived feedstocks, carbonyl compounds, and typical plastic of polycarbonates is introduced.
